title_sort: john m. rogers to walt whitman, 27 february 1871
title: John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 27 February 1871
text: Feb 27th 1871Dear FatherI receive[received] your letter on Saturday and was glad to hear from you and that you are well and enjoying you[your] self I am as well as ever but I feel very uneasy at times because I am doing nothing I have not done any thing scince Jan 1st every thing is very dull here at presant[present] The weather is warm and pleasant here for this time of the year We did not have a very great time on Washington birth day here a reg. or two of Soldiers turned out in a parade was all that I see in this great City I should like very much to come to Washinton[Washington] and see you but as long as I know that you are well and enjoying your self I will try to content my self It rained all day here yesterday and I did not go out any whare[where] I feel very greatful[grateful] to you that you should take so much interist[interest] in me it makes me think of my father all though if we think of our dear heavenly Fathe[Father] he will guide and direct us in all our ways and we ought to be very thankful to him for our good health he is such a good Father to us so good by[bye] for the presant[present] my Dear good Fatherfrom your affecinate[affectionate] SonJohn M RogersP.S. I would come out there on a visit but can not aford[afford] it just now so good by[bye]Jonny John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 27 February 1871
